awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: A Complementary Metal-Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) Compatible Single Photon Avalanche Diode
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to make 3D cameras for long-range LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) more affordable, widespread, and as reliable and simple to use as cameras found in common mobile devices. 3D cameras (LiDAR) are being used for precise positioning and velocity determination of objects in augmented reality applications and are crucial for widespread adoption of autonomous cars and trucks where the 200-300 meter range is required. Eye safety concerns with low-cost silicon sensors force the long-range autonomous vehicle customers to use one pixel at the time or limited field of view imaging using high-cost and complex systems based on materials that require specialty materials and manufacturing. This technology will enable the use of mainstream materials and process technology for the long-range autonomous vehicle segment without compromising eye safety. This capability will reduce cost, lower complexity, and improve reliability of long-range 3D cameras and help propel the autonomous vehicle industry into widespread adoption.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a fully complementary metal-oxide semiconductor compatible single photon avalanche diode (SPADs) based on germanium that operates at eye safe wavelengths. Current germanium-based avalanche photodiodes require cryogenic cooling due to excessive dark noise from tunneling or dislocations.  They suffer from poor absorption at the eye safe wavelengths beyond 1450 nm. This project will implement a photon trapping strained heterostructure device architecture which reduces dark counts while enhancing absorption at the operating wavelength. The device structure will be developed with particular emphasis on the semiconductor growth process. The experimental results will be benchmarked to the dark count and absorption requirements for the mass-market, long-range autonomous vehicle application. The technology will offer a highly manufacturable, lower cost alternative to compound semiconductor based SPADs that are often prohibitively expensive to produce in large arrays.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aimed at developing the key elements of a fully complementary metal-oxide semiconductor compatible single photon avalanche diode (SPADs) based on germanium. Such technology is expected to dramatically reduce cost while improving productivity of 3D cameras for long-range LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging). The technology has implications for the wide-spread adoption of autonomous trucking and would improve the competitiveness of other LiDAR for other long-range applications. This includes LiDAR for geo-mapping applications critical in the technology transformation required to help combat and adapt to climate change, including use of LiDAR for precise mapping of changes in coastal regions and optimization of power transmission line performance. These and other applications were explored in customer discovery.

Historically, germanium based SPADs have suffered from very high dark counts incompatible with such use cases. Thus, the technical work of this project has explored and implemented a novel design that addresses this problem. In one work package, the design was explored by using advanced and calibrated models. We established a four-stage development roadmap to achieve a dark count of 94 kHz in a moderately cooled but scaled SPAD. The design incorporates a strained barrier which reduces dark counts by approximately two orders of magnitude. By further optimization, we anticipate that dark counts could be further improved beyond this road map to a few 10s of kHz. In a second work package, the strained barrier was implemented for the first time in a production-grade epitaxy reactor using only widely available source gases and at temperatures exceeding 500?C. The proof-of-concept doped diode structure was implemented ?in silicon? including annealed ion implants. We showed that the tunnel barrier stays strained throughout the thermal processing required for the proof-of-concept device process. Finally, the lithography masks for the first three stages of the technology road map were designed.  

In conclusion, the project showed that moderately cooled germanium based SPADs could indeed support the dark counts required for long-range 3D camera applications such as geo mapping and autonomous trucking. The key to this is our novel strained barrier diode design. In this project we designed such diodes and demonstrated the novel strained barrier structure experimentally for the first time.

 


Last Modified: 02/07/2023
Modified by: Ingvar Aberg
